title: Scenario 1: Acute Abdomen
diagnosis_topic: Acute Abdomen with Sudden Onset Pain
setup_script: A 62-year-old male presents to the emergency department with severe, diffuse abdominal pain that began suddenly about 4 hours ago. He rates the pain as 9/10 and states it is unlike anything he has experienced before. He reports some nausea but no vomiting. He has been taking ibuprofen regularly for knee pain. Vital signs show: Temperature 38.0°C, HR 110, BP 105/70, RR 22. On examination, his abdomen is rigid with diffuse tenderness and guarding. Initial labs show: WBC 16,000/μL, Hgb 13.5 g/dL, BUN 28 mg/dL, Creatinine 1.3 mg/dL. How would you proceed with this patient?

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident asks for additional history
dynamic_flow.reply: Patient reports taking NSAIDs for knee pain, has history of dyspepsia but never sought treatment. No prior surgeries.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident asks for additional physical exam findings
dynamic_flow.reply: Patient has absent bowel sounds and tympany over the upper abdomen.
You obtain an upright chest X-ray that shows free air under the diaphragm.
CT scan shows free intraperitoneal air and fluid particularly around the duodenum and near the pylorus of the stomach.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident initiates resuscitation and proposes surgical intervention
dynamic_flow.reply: The patient is given IV fluids, antibiotics, and prepared for surgery. What is your operative plan?
During laparoscopy, you identify a 1 cm anterior duodenal perforation with purulent fluid throughout the abdomen. What will you do now?
Upon entering the abdomen, you find a 1 cm anterior duodenal perforation with purulent fluid throughout the abdomen. What will you do now?

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident describes Graham patch repair
dynamic_flow.reply: You successfully perform the repair. How will you manage this patient postoperatively?

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident does not address H. pylori
dynamic_flow.reply: The patient recovers well but returns 6 months later with similar symptoms. What might you have missed?
